# French colonization of the Americas

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Nouvelle-France_map-
en.svg/340px-Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Nouvelle-France_map-
en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Nouvelle-France_map-en.svg "Enlarge")

Map of [North America](/wiki/North_America "North America") (1750) - France
(blue), Britain (pink), and Spain (orange)

The **French colonization of the Americas** began in the 16th century, and
continued on into the following centuries as [France](/wiki/France "France")
established a [colonial empire](/wiki/French_colonial_empire "French colonial
empire") in the [Western Hemisphere](/wiki/Western_Hemisphere "Western
Hemisphere"). France founded colonies in much of eastern North America, on a
number of Caribbean islands, and in South America. Most colonies were
developed to export products such as fish, rice sugar, and furs.

As they colonized the New World, the French established forts and settlements
that would become such cities as [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec_City "Quebec City") and
[Montreal](/wiki/Montreal "Montreal") in Canada;
[Detroit](/wiki/Detroit,_Michigan "Detroit, Michigan"), [Green
Bay](/wiki/Green_Bay,_Wisconsin "Green Bay, Wisconsin"), [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri "St. Louis, Missouri"), [Cape
Girardeau](/wiki/Cape_Girardeau,_Missouri "Cape Girardeau, Missouri"),
[Mobile](/wiki/Mobile,_Alabama "Mobile, Alabama"),
[Biloxi](/wiki/Biloxi,_Mississippi "Biloxi, Mississippi"), [Baton
Rouge](/wiki/Baton_Rouge,_Louisiana "Baton Rouge, Louisiana") and [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans,_Louisiana "New Orleans, Louisiana") in the United
States; and [Port-au-Prince](/wiki/Port-au-Prince "Port-au-Prince"), [Cap-
Haïtien](/wiki/Cap-Ha%C3%AFtien "Cap-Haïtien") (founded as _Cap-Français_) in
[Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti"), [Cayenne](/wiki/Cayenne "Cayenne") in [French
Guiana](/wiki/French_Guiana "French Guiana") and [São
Luís](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Lu%C3%ADs,_Maranh%C3%A3o "São Luís, Maranhão") (founded
as _Saint-Louis de Maragnan_) in Brazil.

## North
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: North America")]

###
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Background")]

The French first came to the New World as explorers, seeking a route to the
Pacific Ocean and wealth. Major French exploration of North America began
under the rule of [Francis I, King of France](/wiki/Francis_I_of_France
"Francis I of France"). In 1524, Francis sent Italian-born [Giovanni da
Verrazzano](/wiki/Giovanni_da_Verrazzano "Giovanni da Verrazzano") to explore
the region between [Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida") and
[Newfoundland](/wiki/Newfoundland_\(island\) "Newfoundland \(island\)") for a
route to the Pacific Ocean. Verrazzano gave the names _Francesca_ and _Nova
Gallia_ to that land between [New Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New Spain") and
English Newfoundland, thus promoting French interests.[1]

###
Colonization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Colonization")]

Main article: [New France](/wiki/New_France "New France")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Cartier.png/220px-
Cartier.png)](/wiki/File:Cartier.png)

[](/wiki/File:Cartier.png "Enlarge")

Portrait of [Jacques Cartier](/wiki/Jacques_Cartier "Jacques Cartier") by
Théophile Hamel, arr. 1844

In 1534, Francis I of France sent [Jacques Cartier](/wiki/Jacques_Cartier
"Jacques Cartier") on the first of three voyages to explore the coast of
Newfoundland and the [St. Lawrence River](/wiki/St._Lawrence_River "St.
Lawrence River"). He founded New France by planting a cross on the shore of
the [Gaspé Peninsula](/wiki/Gasp%C3%A9_Peninsula "Gaspé Peninsula"). The
French subsequently tried to establish several colonies throughout North
America that failed, due to weather, disease, or conflict with other European
powers. Cartier attempted to create the first permanent European settlement in
North America at [Cap-Rouge](/wiki/Cap-Rouge,_Quebec_City "Cap-Rouge, Quebec
City") (Quebec City) in 1541 with 400 settlers but the settlement was
abandoned the next year after bad weather and attacks from [Native
Americans](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas") in the area. A small group of French troops were left on [Parris
Island, South Carolina](/wiki/Parris_Island,_South_Carolina "Parris Island,
South Carolina") in 1562 to build [Charlesfort](/wiki/Charlesfort
"Charlesfort"), but left after a year when they were not resupplied by France.
[Fort Caroline](/wiki/Fort_Caroline "Fort Caroline") established in present-
day [Jacksonville, Florida](/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida "Jacksonville,
Florida"), in 1564, lasted only a year before being destroyed by the Spanish
from [St. Augustine](/wiki/St._Augustine,_Florida "St. Augustine, Florida").
An attempt to settle convicts on [Sable Island](/wiki/Sable_Island "Sable
Island") off Nova Scotia in 1598 failed after a short time. In 1599, a
sixteen-person trading post was established in
[Tadoussac](/wiki/Tadoussac,_Quebec "Tadoussac, Quebec") (in present-day
[Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec")), of which only five men survived the first
winter. In 1604[2] [Pierre Du Gua de Monts](/wiki/Pierre_Du_Gua_de_Monts
"Pierre Du Gua de Monts") and [Samuel de Champlain](/wiki/Samuel_de_Champlain
"Samuel de Champlain") founded a short-lived French colony, the first in
[Acadia](/wiki/Acadia "Acadia"), on [Saint Croix
Island](/wiki/Saint_Croix_Island,_Maine "Saint Croix Island, Maine"),
presently part of the state of [Maine](/wiki/Maine "Maine"), which was much
plagued by illness, perhaps scurvy. The following year the settlement was
moved to [Port Royal](/wiki/Habitation_at_Port-Royal "Habitation at Port-
Royal"), located in present-day [Nova Scotia](/wiki/Nova_Scotia "Nova
Scotia").

[Samuel de Champlain](/wiki/Samuel_de_Champlain "Samuel de Champlain") founded
[Quebec](/wiki/Quebec_City "Quebec City") (1608) and explored the [Great
Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes"). In 1634, [Jean
Nicolet](/wiki/Jean_Nicolet "Jean Nicolet") founded _La Baye des Puants_
(present-day [Green Bay](/wiki/Green_Bay,_Wisconsin "Green Bay, Wisconsin")),
which is one of the oldest permanent European settlements in America. In 1634,
[Sieur de Laviolette](/wiki/Sieur_de_Laviolette "Sieur de Laviolette") founded
Trois-Rivières. In 1642, [Paul de Chomedey, Sieur de
Maisonneuve](/wiki/Paul_de_Chomedey,_Sieur_de_Maisonneuve "Paul de Chomedey,
Sieur de Maisonneuve"), founded [Fort Ville-Marie](/wiki/Fort_Ville-Marie
"Fort Ville-Marie") which is now known as [Montreal](/wiki/Montreal
"Montreal"). [Louis Jolliet](/wiki/Louis_Jolliet "Louis Jolliet") and [Jacques
Marquette](/wiki/Jacques_Marquette "Jacques Marquette") founded [Sault Sainte
Marie](/wiki/Sault_Ste._Marie,_Michigan "Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan") (1668)
and [Saint Ignace](/wiki/St._Ignace,_Michigan "St. Ignace, Michigan") (1671)
and explored the [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi
River"). At the end of the 17th century, [René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La
Salle](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9-Robert_Cavelier,_Sieur_de_La_Salle "René-Robert
Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle") established a network of forts going from the
[Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") to the Great Lakes and
the [Saint Lawrence River](/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_River "Saint Lawrence River").
[Fort Saint Louis](/wiki/French_colonization_of_Texas "French colonization of
Texas") was established in Texas in 1685, but was gone by 1688. [Antoine de la
Mothe Cadillac](/wiki/Antoine_de_la_Mothe_Cadillac "Antoine de la Mothe
Cadillac") founded _[Fort Pontchartrain du Détroit](/wiki/Fort_Detroit "Fort
Detroit")_ (modern-day [Detroit](/wiki/Detroit "Detroit")) in 1701 and [Jean-
Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de Bienville](/wiki/Jean-
Baptiste_Le_Moyne,_Sieur_de_Bienville "Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de
Bienville") founded _La Nouvelle Orléans_ ([New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans
"New Orleans")) in 1718. [Pierre Le Moyne
d'Iberville](/wiki/Pierre_Le_Moyne_d%27Iberville "Pierre Le Moyne
d'Iberville") founded [Baton Rouge](/wiki/Baton_Rouge "Baton Rouge") in 1719.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Frontenac_with_the_Indians.jpg/220px-
Frontenac_with_the_Indians.jpg)](/wiki/File:Frontenac_with_the_Indians.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Frontenac_with_the_Indians.jpg "Enlarge")

Governor [Frontenac](/wiki/Louis_de_Buade_de_Frontenac "Louis de Buade de
Frontenac") performing a tribal dance with Indian allies

.[3]

The French were eager to explore North America but New France remained largely
unpopulated. Due to the lack of women, intermarriages between French and
Indians were frequent, giving rise to the [Métis
people](/wiki/M%C3%A9tis_people_\(Canada\) "Métis people \(Canada\)").
Relations between the French and Indians were usually peaceful. As the 19th-
century historian [Francis Parkman](/wiki/Francis_Parkman "Francis Parkman")
stated:

> "Spanish civilization crushed the Indian; English civilization scorned and
> neglected him; French civilization embraced and cherished him"
>
> — Francis Parkman.[4]

To boost the French population, [Cardinal Richelieu](/wiki/Cardinal_Richelieu
"Cardinal Richelieu") issued an act declaring that Indians converted to
Catholicism were considered as "natural Frenchmen" by the
[Ordonnance](/wiki/Ordonnance "Ordonnance") of 1627:

> "The descendants of the French who are accustomed to this country [New
> France], together with all the Indians who will be brought to the knowledge
> of the faith and will profess it, shall be deemed and renowned natural
> Frenchmen, and as such may come to live in France when they want, and
> acquire, donate, and succeed and accept donations and legacies, just as true
> French subjects, without being required to take no letters of declaration of
> naturalization."[5]

[Louis XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France "Louis XIV of France") also tried to
increase the population by sending approximately 800 young women nicknamed the
"[King's Daughters](/wiki/King%27s_Daughters "King's Daughters")". However,
the low density of population in New France remained a very persistent
problem. At the beginning of the [French and Indian
War](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War") (1754–1763), the
British population in North America outnumbered the French 20 to 1. France
fought a total of six colonial wars in North America (see the four [French and
Indian Wars](/wiki/French_and_Indian_Wars "French and Indian Wars") as well as
[Father Rale's War](/wiki/Father_Rale%27s_War "Father Rale's War") and [Father
Le Loutre's War](/wiki/Father_Le_Loutre%27s_War "Father Le Loutre's War")).[6]

See also: [Franco-Indian alliance](/wiki/Franco-Indian_alliance "Franco-Indian
alliance")

### French
Florida[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: French Florida")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nouvelle-
France_floridienne.png/220px-Nouvelle-
France_floridienne.png)](/wiki/File:Nouvelle-France_floridienne.png)

[](/wiki/File:Nouvelle-France_floridienne.png "Enlarge")

Map of French Florida

In 1562, [Charles IX](/wiki/Charles_IX_of_France "Charles IX of France"),
under the leadership of Admiral [Gaspard de
Coligny](/wiki/Gaspard_II_de_Coligny "Gaspard II de Coligny") sent [Jean
Ribault](/wiki/Jean_Ribault "Jean Ribault") and a group of
[Huguenot](/wiki/Huguenot "Huguenot") settlers in an attempt to colonize the
Atlantic coast and found a colony on a territory which will take the name of
the [French Florida](/wiki/French_Florida "French Florida"). They discovered
the probe and Port Royal Island, which will be called by [Parris
Island](/wiki/Parris_Island "Parris Island") in [South
Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina"), on which he built a fort
named [Charlesfort](/wiki/Charlesfort "Charlesfort"). The group, led by [René
Goulaine de Laudonnière](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Goulaine_de_Laudonni%C3%A8re "René
Goulaine de Laudonnière"), moved to the south where they founded the [Fort
Caroline](/wiki/Fort_Caroline "Fort Caroline") on the Saint John's river in
[Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida") on June 22, 1564.[7]

This irritated the Spanish who claimed Florida and opposed the
[Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") settlers for religious reasons. In
1565, [Pedro Menéndez de Avilés](/wiki/Pedro_Men%C3%A9ndez_de_Avil%C3%A9s
"Pedro Menéndez de Avilés") led a group of Spaniards and founded [Saint
Augustine](/wiki/Saint_Augustine,_Florida "Saint Augustine, Florida"), 60
kilometers south of Fort Caroline. Fearing a Spanish attack, Ribault planned
to move the colony but a [storm](/wiki/Storm "Storm") suddenly destroyed his
fleet. On 20 September 1565 the Spaniards, commanded by Menéndez de Avilés,
attacked and massacred all the Fort Caroline occupants including Jean
Ribault.[8]

### Canada and
Acadia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Canada and Acadia")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/1664AmeriqueNord.jpg/300px-1664AmeriqueNord.jpg)](/wiki/File:1664AmeriqueNord.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1664AmeriqueNord.jpg "Enlarge")

Political map of the Northeastern part of North America in 1664.

The French interest in Canada focused first on fishing off the [Grand
Banks](/wiki/Grand_Banks "Grand Banks") of Newfoundland. However, at the
beginning of the 17th century, France was more interested in fur from North
America. The fur trading post of [Tadoussac](/wiki/Tadoussac "Tadoussac") was
founded in 1600. Four years later, [Champlain](/wiki/Samuel_de_Champlain
"Samuel de Champlain") made his first trip to Canada in a trade mission for
fur. Although he had no formal mandate on this trip, he sketched a map of the
St. Lawrence River and in writing, on his return to France, a report entitled
_Savages_[9] (Relation of his stay in a tribe of
[Montagnais](/wiki/Innu_people "Innu people") near Tadoussac).

Champlain needed to report his findings to [Henry IV](/wiki/Henry_IV_of_France
"Henry IV of France"). He participated in another expedition to New France in
the spring of 1604, conducted by [Pierre Du Gua de
Monts](/wiki/Pierre_Du_Gua_de_Monts "Pierre Du Gua de Monts"). It helped the
foundation of a settlement on [Saint Croix
Island](/wiki/Saint_Croix_Island,_Maine "Saint Croix Island, Maine"), the
first French settlement in the New World, which would be given up the
following winter. The expedition then founded the colony of [Port-
Royal](/wiki/Habitation_at_Port-Royal "Habitation at Port-Royal").

In 1608, Champlain founded a fur post that would become the city of
[Quebec](/wiki/Quebec_\(city\) "Quebec \(city\)"), which would become the
capital of New France. In Quebec, Champlain forged alliances between France
and the [Huron](/wiki/Huron-Wendat_Nation "Huron-Wendat Nation") and
[Ottawa](/wiki/Odawa "Odawa") against their traditional enemies, the
[Iroquois](/wiki/Iroquois "Iroquois"). Champlain and other French travelers
then continued to explore North America, with [canoes](/wiki/Canoe "Canoe")
made from [Birch](/wiki/Birch "Birch") [bark](/wiki/Bark_\(botany\) "Bark
\(botany\)"), to move quickly through the [Great
Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes_\(North_America\) "Great Lakes \(North America\)")
and their tributaries. In 1634, the Normand explorer [Jean
Nicolet](/wiki/Jean_Nicolet "Jean Nicolet") pushed his exploration to the West
up to Wisconsin.[10]

Following the capitulation of Quebec by the [Kirke](/wiki/David_Kirke "David
Kirke") brothers, the British occupied the city of Quebec and Canada from 1629
to 1632. Samuel de Champlain was taken prisoner and there followed the
bankruptcy of the [Company of One Hundred
Associates](/wiki/Company_of_One_Hundred_Associates "Company of One Hundred
Associates"). Following the [Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-
Laye](/wiki/Treaty_of_Saint-Germain-en-Laye_\(1632\) "Treaty of Saint-Germain-
en-Laye \(1632\)"), France took possession of the colony in 1632. The city of
[Trois-Rivières](/wiki/Trois-Rivi%C3%A8res "Trois-Rivières") was founded in
1634. In 1642, the Angevin [Jérôme le Royer de la
Dauversière](/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_le_Royer_de_la_Dauversi%C3%A8re "Jérôme le
Royer de la Dauversière") founded [Ville-Marie](/wiki/Fort_Ville-Marie "Fort
Ville-Marie") (later [Montreal](/wiki/Montreal "Montreal")) which was at that
time, a fort as protection against Iroquois attacks (the first great Iroquois
war lasted from 1642 to 1667).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/A_new_map_of_the_north_parts_of_America_claimed_by_France_under_ye_names_of_Louisiana..._%282674873145%29.jpg/350px-
A_new_map_of_the_north_parts_of_America_claimed_by_France_under_ye_names_of_Louisiana..._%282674873145%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_new_map_of_the_north_parts_of_America_claimed_by_France_under_ye_names_of_Louisiana..._\(2674873145\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:A_new_map_of_the_north_parts_of_America_claimed_by_France_under_ye_names_of_Louisiana..._\(2674873145\).jpg
"Enlarge")

A new map of the north parts of America claimed by France in 1720, according
to the London cartographer [Herman Moll](/wiki/Herman_Moll "Herman Moll").

Despite this rapid expansion, the colony developed very slowly. The Iroquois
wars and diseases were the leading causes of death in the French colony. In
1663 when [Louis XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France "Louis XIV of France")
provided the _Royal Government_ , the population of New France was only 2500
European inhabitants. That year, to increase the population, Louis XIV sent
between 800 and 900 '[King's Daughters](/wiki/King%27s_Daughters "King's
Daughters")' to become the wives of French settlers. The population of New
France reached subsequently 7000 in 1674 and 15000 in 1689.[11][12]

From 1689 to 1713, the French settlers were faced with almost incessant war
during the [French and Indian Wars](/wiki/French_and_Indian_Wars "French and
Indian Wars"). From 1689 to 1697, they fought the British in the [Nine Years'
War](/wiki/Nine_Years%27_War "Nine Years' War"). The war against the Iroquois
continued even after the [Treaty of Rijswijk](/wiki/Treaty_of_Rijswijk "Treaty
of Rijswijk") until 1701, when the two parties agreed on peace. Then, the war
against the English took over in the [War of the Spanish
Succession](/wiki/War_of_the_Spanish_Succession "War of the Spanish
Succession"). In 1690 and 1711, Quebec City had successfully resisted the
attacks of the English navy and then British army. Nevertheless, the British
took advantage of the second war. With the signing of the [Treaty of
Utrecht](/wiki/Treaty_of_Utrecht "Treaty of Utrecht") in 1713, France ceded to
Britain Acadia (with a population of 1700 people),
[Newfoundland](/wiki/Newfoundland "Newfoundland") and [Hudson
Bay](/wiki/Hudson_Bay "Hudson Bay"). Under the Sovereign Council, the
population of the colony grew faster. However, the population growth was far
inferior to that of the British [Thirteen Colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies
"Thirteen Colonies") to the south. In the middle of the 18th century, New
France accounted for 60,000 people while the British colonies had more than
one million people. This placed the colony at a great military disadvantage
against the British. The war between the colonies resumed in 1744, lasting
until 1748. A final and decisive war began in 1754. The
[Canadiens](/wiki/Canadiens "Canadiens") and the French were helped by
numerous alliances with Native Americans, but they were usually outnumbered on
the battlefield.[13]

###
Louisiana[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Louisiana")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/La_Nouvelle-
France.jpg/300px-La_Nouvelle-France.jpg)](/wiki/File:La_Nouvelle-France.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:La_Nouvelle-France.jpg "Enlarge")

Louisiana before 1736

On May 17, 1673, explorers [Louis Jolliet](/wiki/Louis_Jolliet "Louis
Jolliet") and [Jacques Marquette](/wiki/Jacques_Marquette "Jacques Marquette")
began exploring the Mississippi River, known to the Sioux as _does Tongo,_ or
to the [Miami-Illinois](/wiki/Miami-Illinois_language "Miami-Illinois
language") as _missisipioui_ (_the great river_). They reached the mouth of
the Arkansas and then up the river, after learning that it flowed into the
Gulf of Mexico and not to the California Sea (Pacific Ocean).[14]

In 1682, the Normand [Cavelier de la
Salle](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9-Robert_Cavelier,_Sieur_de_La_Salle "René-Robert
Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle") and the Italian [Henri de
Tonti](/wiki/Henri_de_Tonti "Henri de Tonti") came down the Mississippi to its
Delta. They left from [Fort Crevecoeur](/wiki/Fort_Crevecoeur "Fort
Crevecoeur") on the Illinois River, along with 23 French and 18 Native
Americans. In April 1682, they arrived at the mouth of the Mississippi; they
planted a cross and a column bearing the arms of the king of France. La Salle
returned to France and won over the [Secretary of State of the
Navy](/wiki/Minist%C3%A8re_de_la_Marine "Ministère de la Marine") to give him
the command of [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_France\) "Louisiana \(New
France\)"). He believed that it was close to [New Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New
Spain") by drawing a map on which the Mississippi seemed much further west
than its actual rate. He set up a maritime expedition with four ships and 320
emigrants, but it ended in disaster when he failed to find the Mississippi
Delta and was killed in 1687.[15]

In 1698, [Pierre LeMoyne d'Iberville](/wiki/Pierre_LeMoyne_d%27Iberville
"Pierre LeMoyne d'Iberville") left [La Rochelle](/wiki/La_Rochelle "La
Rochelle") and explored the area around the mouth of the Mississippi. He
stopped between Isle-aux-Chats (now Cat Island) and Isle Surgeres (renamed
Isle-aux-Vascular or Ship Island) on February 13, 1699 and continued his
explorations to the mainland, with his brother [Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne de
Bienville](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Le_Moyne_de_Bienville "Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne
de Bienville") to [Biloxi](/wiki/Biloxi,_Mississippi "Biloxi, Mississippi").
He built a precarious fort, called 'Maurepas' (later 'Old Biloxi'), before
returning to France. He returned twice in the Gulf of Mexico and established a
fort at [Mobile](/wiki/Mobile,_Alabama "Mobile, Alabama") in 1702.

From 1699 to 1702, Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville was governor of Louisiana. His
brother succeeded him in that post from 1702 to 1713. He was again governor
from 1716 to 1724 and again 1733 to 1743. In 1718, Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne de
Bienville commanded a French expedition in Louisiana. He founded the city of
New Orleans, in homage to [Regent](/wiki/Regency "Regency") [Duke of
Orleans](/wiki/Philippe_II,_Duke_of_Orl%C3%A9ans "Philippe II, Duke of
Orléans"). The architect [Adrian de Pauger](/wiki/Adrian_de_Pauger "Adrian de
Pauger") drew the orthogonal plane of the [Old Square](/wiki/French_Quarter
"French Quarter").

#### The Mississippi
Bubble[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: The Mississippi Bubble")]

Main article: [Mississippi Company](/wiki/Mississippi_Company "Mississippi
Company")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Weigel_La_Louisiane_1719_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1017_01.jpg/220px-
Weigel_La_Louisiane_1719_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1017_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Weigel_La_Louisiane_1719_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1017_01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Weigel_La_Louisiane_1719_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1017_01.jpg "Enlarge")

In Weigel's map (1719) intended to promote sales of the Mississippi Company in
Germany; most of the present-day United States appears under the name
"Louisiana".

In 1718, there were only 700 Europeans in Louisiana. The Mississippi Company
arranged for ships to bring 800 more, who landed in Louisiana in 1718,
doubling the European population. [John Law](/wiki/John_Law_\(economist\)
"John Law \(economist\)") encouraged [Germans](/wiki/German_people "German
people"), particularly Germans of the [Alsatian](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace") region
who had [recently fallen under French
rule](/wiki/Alsace#Incorporation_into_France "Alsace"), and the
[Swiss](/wiki/Swiss_people "Swiss people") to emigrate.

Prisoners were set free in Paris in September 1719 onwards, under the
condition that they marry prostitutes and go with them to Louisiana. The newly
married couples were chained together and taken to the port of embarkation. In
May 1720, after complaints from the Mississippi Company and the concessioners
about this class of French immigrants, the French government prohibited such
deportations. However, there was a third shipment of prisoners in 1721.[16]

###
Dissolution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Dissolution")]

The last [French and Indian War](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and
Indian War") resulted in the dissolution of [New France](/wiki/New_France "New
France"), with [Canada](/wiki/Canada_\(New_France\) "Canada \(New France\)")
going to [Great Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great
Britain") and [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_France\) "Louisiana \(New
France\)") going to [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain"). Only the islands of [Saint-
Pierre-et-Miquelon](/wiki/Saint_Pierre_and_Miquelon "Saint Pierre and
Miquelon") are still in French hands.

In 1802 Spain returned Louisiana to France, but [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon
"Napoleon") [sold it](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase "Louisiana Purchase") to the
United States in 1803. The French left many [toponyms](/wiki/Toponym
"Toponym") ([Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"), [Vermont](/wiki/Vermont
"Vermont"), [Bayous](/wiki/Bayou "Bayou")...) and [ethnonyms](/wiki/Ethnonym
"Ethnonym") ([Sioux](/wiki/Sioux "Sioux"), [Coeur
d'Alene](/wiki/Coeur_d%27Alene_people "Coeur d'Alene people"), [Nez
Percé](/wiki/Nez_Perce_people "Nez Perce people")...) in North America.

## West
Indies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: West Indies")]

Further information: [French West Indies](/wiki/French_West_Indies "French
West Indies")

A major French settlement lay on the island of [Hispaniola](/wiki/Hispaniola
"Hispaniola"), where France established the colony of [Saint-
Domingue](/wiki/Saint-Domingue "Saint-Domingue") on the western third of the
island[17] in 1664. Nicknamed the "Pearl of the Antilles", Saint-Domingue
became the richest colony in the Caribbean due to slave plantation production
of sugar cane. It had the highest slave mortality rate in the western
hemisphere.[18] A 1791 slave revolt, the only ever successful slave revolt,
began the [Haitian Revolution](/wiki/Haitian_Revolution "Haitian Revolution"),
led to freedom for the colony's slaves in 1794 and, a decade later, complete
independence for the country, which renamed itself [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti
"Haiti"). France briefly also ruled the eastern portion of the island, which
is now the [Dominican Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican
Republic").

During the 17th and 18th centuries, France ruled much of the [Lesser
Antilles](/wiki/Lesser_Antilles "Lesser Antilles") at various times. Islands
that came under French rule during part or all of this time include
[Dominica](/wiki/Dominica "Dominica"), [Grenada](/wiki/Grenada "Grenada"),
[Guadeloupe](/wiki/Guadeloupe "Guadeloupe"), [Marie-Galante](/wiki/Marie-
Galante "Marie-Galante"), [Martinique](/wiki/Martinique "Martinique"), [St.
Barthélemy](/wiki/Saint-Barth%C3%A9lemy "Saint-Barthélemy"), [St.
Croix](/wiki/St._Croix "St. Croix"), [St. Kitts](/wiki/St._Kitts "St. Kitts"),
[St. Lucia](/wiki/St._Lucia "St. Lucia"), [St. Martin](/wiki/Saint_Martin
"Saint Martin"), [St. Vincent](/wiki/St._Vincent_\(island\) "St. Vincent
\(island\)") and [Tobago](/wiki/Tobago "Tobago"). Control of many of these
islands was contested between the French, the British and the Dutch; in the
case of St. Martin, the island was divided in two, a situation that persists
to this day. [Great Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great
Britain") captured some of France's islands during the [Seven Years'
War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven Years' War")[19] and the [Napoleonic
Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars"). Following the latter conflict,
France retained control of [Guadeloupe](/wiki/Guadeloupe "Guadeloupe"),
[Martinique](/wiki/Martinique "Martinique"), [Marie-Galante](/wiki/Marie-
Galante "Marie-Galante"), [St. Barthélemy](/wiki/St._Barth%C3%A9lemy "St.
Barthélemy"), and its portion of [St. Martin](/wiki/Saint_Martin "Saint
Martin"); all remain part of France today. Guadeloupe (including Marie-Galante
and other nearby islands) and Martinique each is an [overseas
department](/wiki/Overseas_department "Overseas department") of France, while
St. Barthélemy and St. Martin each became an [overseas
collectivity](/wiki/Overseas_collectivity "Overseas collectivity") of France
in 2007.

###
Brazil[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Brazil")]

France Antarctique (formerly also spelled France antartique) was a French
colony south of the [Equator](/wiki/Equator "Equator"), in [Rio de
Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro"), [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil
"Brazil"), which existed between 1555 and 1567, and had control over the coast
from Rio de Janeiro to [Cabo Frio](/wiki/Cabo_Frio "Cabo Frio"). The colony
quickly became a haven for the [Huguenots](/wiki/Huguenots "Huguenots"), and
was ultimately destroyed by the Portuguese in 1567. On November 1, 1555,
French vice-admiral [Nicolas Durand de
Villegaignon](/wiki/Nicolas_Durand_de_Villegaignon "Nicolas Durand de
Villegaignon") (1510–1575), a Catholic knight of the [Order of
Malta](/wiki/Order_of_Malta "Order of Malta"), who later would help the
Huguenots to find a refuge against persecution, led a small fleet of two ships
and 600 soldiers and colonists, and took possession of the small island of
[Serigipe](/wiki/Villegagnon_Island "Villegagnon Island") in the [Guanabara
Bay](/wiki/Guanabara_Bay "Guanabara Bay"), in front of present-day Rio de
Janeiro, where they built a fort named Fort Coligny. The fort was named in
honor of [Gaspard de Coligny](/wiki/Gaspard_II_de_Coligny "Gaspard II de
Coligny") (then a Catholic statesman, who about a year later would become a
Huguenot), an admiral who supported the expedition and would use the colony in
order to protect his co-religionists. To the still largely undeveloped
mainland village, Villegaignon gave the name of Henriville, in honour of
[Henry II](/wiki/Henry_II_of_France "Henry II of France"), the [King of
France](/wiki/King_of_France "King of France"), who also knew of and approved
the expedition, and had provided the fleet for the trip. Villegaignon secured
his position by making an alliance with the [Tamoio](/wiki/Tamoio "Tamoio")
and [Tupinambá](/wiki/Tupinamb%C3%A1_people "Tupinambá people") Indians of the
region, who were fighting the Portuguese.

#### 1557 Calvinist
arrival[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: 1557 Calvinist arrival")]

Unchallenged by the Portuguese, who initially took little notice of his
landing, Villegaignon endeavoured to expand the colony by calling for more
colonists in 1556. He sent one of his ships, the Grande Roberge, to Honfleur,
entrusted with letters to King Henry II, Gaspard de Coligny and according to
some accounts, the Protestant leader John Calvin. After one ship was sent to
France to ask for additional support, three ships were financed and prepared
by the king of France and put under the command of Sieur De Bois le Comte, a
nephew of Villegagnon. They were joined by 14 Calvinists from Geneva, led by
Philippe de Corguilleray, including theologians Pierre Richier and Guillaume
Chartrier. The new colonists, numbering around 300, included 5 young women to
be wed, 10 boys to be trained as translators, as well as 14 Calvinists sent by
Calvin, and also Jean de Léry, who would later write an account of the colony.
They arrived in March 1557. The relief fleet was composed of: The Petite
Roberge, with 80 soldiers and sailors was led by Vice Admiral Sieur De Bois le
Comte. The Grande Roberge, with about 120 on board, captained by Sieur de
Sainte-Marie dit l'Espine. The Rosée, with about 90 people, led by Captain
Rosée. Doctrinal disputes arose between Villegagnon and the Calvinists,
especially in relation to the Eucharist, and in October 1557 the Calvinists
were banished from Coligny island as a result. They settled among the
Tupinamba until January 1558, when some of them managed to return to France by
ship together with Jean de Léry, and five others chose to return to Coligny
island where three of them were drowned by Villegagnon for refusing to recant.

#### Portuguese
intervention[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Portuguese intervention")]

In 1560 Mem de Sá, the new Governor-General of Brazil, received from the
Portuguese government the command to expel the French. With a fleet of 26
warships and 2,000 soldiers, on 15 March 1560, he attacked and destroyed Fort
Coligny within three days, but was unable to drive off their inhabitants and
defenders, because they escaped to the mainland with the help of the Native
Brazilians, where they continued to live and to work. Admiral Villegaignon had
returned to France in 1558, disgusted with the religious tension that existed
between French Protestants and Catholics, who had come also with the second
group (see French Wars of Religion). Urged by two influential Jesuit priests
who had come to Brazil with Mem de Sá, named José de Anchieta and Manuel da
Nóbrega, and who had played a big role in pacifying the Tamoios, Mem de Sá
ordered his nephew, Estácio de Sá to assemble a new attack force. Estácio de
Sá founded the city of Rio de Janeiro on March 1, 1565, and fought the
Frenchmen for two more years. Helped by a military reinforcement sent by his
uncle, on January 20, 1567, he imposed final defeat on the French forces and
decisively expelled them from Brazil, but died a month later from wounds
inflicted in the battle. Coligny's and Villegaignon's dream had lasted a mere
12 years.

### Equinoctial
France[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Equinoctial France")]

Equinoctial France was the contemporary name given to the colonization efforts
of France in the 17th century in South America, around the line of Equator,
before "tropical" had fully gained its modern meaning: Equinoctial means in
Latin "of equal nights", i.e., on the Equator, where the duration of days and
nights is nearly the same year round. The French colonial empire in the New
World also included New France (Nouvelle France) in North America,
particularly in what is today the province of Quebec, Canada, and for a very
short period (12 years) also Antarctic France (France Antarctique, in French),
in present-day Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. All of these settlements were in
violation of the papal bull of 1493, which divided the New World between Spain
and Portugal. This division was later defined more exactly by the Treaty of
Tordesillas.

### History of France
Équinoxiale[[edit](/w/index.php?title=French_colonization_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: History of France Équinoxiale")]

France Équinoxiale started in 1612, when a French expedition departed from
Cancale, Brittany, France, under the command of Daniel de la Touche, Seigneur
de la Ravardière, and François de Razilly, admiral. Carrying 500 colonists, it
arrived in the Northern coast of what is today the Brazilian state of
Maranhão. De la Ravardière had discovered the region in 1604 but the death of
the king postponed his plans to start its colonization. The colonists soon
founded a village, which was named "Saint-Louis", in honor of the French king
Louis IX. This later became São Luís in Portuguese,[1] the only Brazilian
state capital founded by France. On 8 September, Capuchin friars prayed the
first mass, and the soldiers started building a fortress. An important
difference in relation to France Antarctique is that this new colony was not
motivated by escape from religious persecutions to Protestants (see French
Wars of Religion). The colony did not last long. A Portuguese army assembled
in the Captaincy of Pernambuco, under the command of Alexandre de Moura, was
able to mount a military expedition, which defeated and expelled the French
colonists in 1615, less than four years after their arrival in the land. Thus,
it repeated the disaster spelt for the colonists of France Antarctique, in
1567. A few years later, in 1620, Portuguese and Brazilian colonists arrived
in number and São Luís started to develop, with an economy based mostly in
sugar cane and slavery.

French traders and colonists tried again to settle a France Équinoxiale
further North, in what is today French Guiana, in 1626, 1635 (when the
capital, Cayenne, was founded) and 1643. Twice a Compagnie de la France
Équinoxiale was founded, in 1643 and 1645, but both foundered as a result of
misfortune and mismanagement. It was only after 1674, when the colony came
under the direct control of the French crown and a competent Governor took
office, that France Équinoxiale became a reality. To this day, French Guiana
is a department of France.[20]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/French_Guiana_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/150px-
French_Guiana_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png)](/wiki/File:French_Guiana_\(orthographic_projection\).svg)

[](/wiki/File:French_Guiana_\(orthographic_projection\).svg "Enlarge")

[French Guiana](/wiki/French_Guiana "French Guiana") located in the South
American continent.

[French Guiana](/wiki/French_Guiana "French Guiana") was first settled by the
French in 1604, although its earliest settlements were abandoned in the face
of hostilities from the [indigenous
population](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of
the Americas") and tropical diseases. The settlement of
[Cayenne](/wiki/Cayenne "Cayenne") was established in 1643, but was abandoned.
It was re-established in the 1660s. Except for brief occupations by the
English and Dutch in the 17th century, and by the Portuguese in the 19th
century, Guiana has remained under French rule ever since. From 1851 to 1951
it was the site of a notorious [penal colony](/wiki/Penal_colony "Penal
colony"), [Devil's Island](/wiki/Devil%27s_Island "Devil's Island") (_Île du
Diable_). Since 1946, French Guiana has been an [overseas
department](/wiki/Overseas_department "Overseas department") of France.[21]
